Empires & Puzzles Ironmaw Review: The Anti-Dark Specialist

Ironmaw bursts onto the scene with a kit designed to punish Dark enemies. But with Average speed and stats that are starting to show their age, is this Orc Warlord still a chain-wielding menace, or has the meta left him in the dust? We break down his anti-Dark mechanics and mana control.
Ironmaw: The Anti-Dark Warlord or Yesterday's News?
Ironmaw, The Anti-Dark Warlord: Smashing Purple or Getting Smashed?
Ironmaw is a 5-star Legendary Holy hero from the

family (Contest of Elements), released back in late 2023. He enters the arena as a specialized "Anti-Dark" brawler, designed to punish purple tanks and flanks with extreme prejudice. While his concept is solid—hit the target and chain that damage to all enemies of the opposing element—he finds himself in a tricky spot. He’s an Average speed hero in a Fast speed world, and his "modern" stats from 2023 are looking a bit like "ancient history" compared to the 1300+ Attack monsters released in late 2025.

Ironmaw looks exactly like what his name suggests: a hulking Orc Warlord with a jaw of gold (or perhaps... iron painted yellow?). He sports a cybernetic/magical arm and wields glowing chains of light, giving off a "techno-barbarian" aesthetic. It's aggressive, it's bold, and it screams "I'm going to hit you with a very heavy object." The purple background contrasts nicely with his yellow armor, hinting at his role as the bane of all things Dark.
When Ironmaw was released, his stats were top-tier. Today, they are merely
This was once impressive. Now, with recent heroes pushing 1300-1400 base attack, Ironmaw hits significantly softer than the current meta attackers.
These defensive stats are decent but won't hold up long against modern snipers who can deal 600%+ damage. He needs Limit Breaks and emblems just to survive the first few turns.
Ironmaw's special is a conditional AoE.
damage to your selected target. This is a solid sniper hit, though at Average speed, it's not groundbreaking.
. This is his gimmick. Against a defense with 2 or 3 Dark heroes, Ironmaw becomes a wrecking ball, effectively hitting multiple targets for sniper-level damage.

If the enemy team has no Dark heroes, Ironmaw is just a slow-ish sniper who slows down mana. He loses a huge chunk of his damage potential.

Family Bonus, Passives, Aether Power & Unique Abilities
The Super Elemental family is all about punishing the weaker element and manipulating the board.

are a fun mechanic. For every Holy hero on your team, a shield transforms into a Power Gem each turn. These deal 20 damage to a random enemy per turn and 10 damage to all enemies when matched. It's free chip damage that adds up over a long fight, stripping away minion layers or finishing off low-HP foes.
against Dark. This means his tile damage against purple tanks is absolutely nuclear. Even with his lower attack stat, a 3-tile match into a purple hero will hurt.

is simple and effective. Given that his main job is to hit hard, boosting his attack stat helps close the gap (slightly) with modern heroes.
Upon release, Ironmaw was seen as a solid counter to the heavy Dark metas (think Alfrike, Ludwig, Aramis). He was a "safe" pick to dismantle purple-heavy teams.
The creep has been unkind. His damage multiplier (500%) was buffed (originally 480%), but his base stats are now far behind. He struggles to one-shot modern heroes who often have 2500+ HP.
. He is not a generalist. You bring him
when you see 2 or more Dark heroes on a defense, or perhaps against a very annoying Purple tank in war. In neutral matchups, there are far better options.
Ironmaw is a Barbarian. This class is generally considered one of the weaker ones (Bleed damage is negligible), but the stats are what we care about.
Maximizes his tile damage (which is doubled against Dark) and his special skill punch. He needs every point of Attack he can get to remain relevant.
Keeps him alive long enough to fire his Average speed skill, applying the crucial Mana Gen debuff.
His damage might barely scratch modern tanks.
. Ironmaw's primary utility is killing Dark heroes with tiles and specials. If he hits like a wet noodle, he's useless. Rely on his passive damage reduction and healers to keep him alive.
Deals massive damage to Dark heroes and extends debilitating ailments on them.
+100% elemental damage from troops makes his tiles deadly against Purple.
enemies is excellent for stalling the opponent.
Against Dark foes, the mana slow cannot be removed, shutting them down for a long time.
If there are no Dark enemies, he is just a mediocre single-target sniper.
In a meta dominated by Fast/Very Fast heroes, 10 tiles can feel like an eternity.
His base stats make it hard for him to compete with the sheer bulk of newer heroes.
Barbarian bleed is rarely a game-changer.
specifically against teams running Purple Tanks or double Purple flanks.
His Average speed becomes Very Fast, allowing him to apply that massive Mana Gen debuff early.
If Yellow is allowed and Purple is not restricted, he shines.
His high tile damage against Dark Titans is excellent, though his special animation is a bit slow.
. You want to play him in a 3-2 or 4-1 Holy stack to maximize the Super Elemental Family bonus (more Power Gems) and tile damage.
Drop the enemy's defense and elemental defense, then let Ironmaw fire. The stacked multipliers will ensure even a modern Purple tank evaporates.
Ironmaw slows their generation (-39%), while Li Xiu and Chao steal/cut the mana they
gain. The enemy will never fire.
They can resist his mana ailment.
Their skin/damage reduction can mitigate his hit significantly.
Don't bring him against non-Dark teams. Seriously. Just don't.

If you pulled Ironmaw early, he is a fantastic asset. He will carry you through map stages (especially Season 1 and 2 where Dark bosses are common) and help you punch above your weight in raids against Purple tanks. Max him out, but maybe save your Limit Break materials for a more versatile hero later.
Ironmaw is a tool in your shed, not your everyday driver. He comes out for specific War hits against heavy Purple teams. He is
worth Alpha Aethers or a second Limit Break unless you are swimming in materials or absolutely love his design. There are simply better Holy heroes (Ogima, Erlang Shen, Shaal) who do more damage to
The community reaction to Ironmaw has been mixed but generally respectful of his niche.
"He will obliterate purple mono teams... I feel like people forget how high his atk stat is to multiply against his ability stat."
- A prescient observer from his release, though that "high atk stat" is now average.
"Literally billions of possible titles and art designs, yet these mofos chose to put this discount ‘Luke Cage meets Village People’ in 'chains of light'."
- A critique on his fashion choices.
"Most defenses will only have one dark enemy, so 500% at average to one is pretty weak."
- A valid criticism that holds true today.

Ironmaw is the definition of a "Silver Bullet." When the conditions are right (Purple tank, Purple flanks), he hits like a truck and shuts down the enemy team with unmatched efficiency. When the conditions are wrong, he's a rusty old tractor trying to keep up with Ferraris. Use him wisely, point him at the shadows, and watch him work. Just don't expect him to carry the team against a rainbow defense of modern gods.
A solid B-tier hero who rises to A-tier against Dark-heavy teams. Keep him for depth, but don't prioritize him over modern powerhouses.
